title: Sources
text:
The clinical data used in this project was obtained from the Genomic Data Commons (GDC), a comprehensive platform managed by the National Cancer Institute (NCI) that provides open access to cancer genomics datasets. Specifically, the dataset focused on Acute Myeloid Leukemia (AML) and includes survival outcomes, treatment responses, and demographic information. This publicly available data supports transparent and reproducible cancer research.
GDC Data Portal: https://portal.gdc.cancer.gov

title: About
text:
Hi! I‚Äôm Darakhshan Fatima, and I love science and oncology. I chose to explore survival analysis as part of my journey into understanding complex biological and clinical data particularly in the context of cancer research.
This website showcases an analysis of real-world clinical data from Acute Myeloid Leukemia (AML) patients, using statistical methods and interactive plots to visualize survival trends and treatment outcomes. By combining my background in life sciences with data analytics, I aim to bridge the gap between biology and data-driven insights.

title: Survival Analysis of Acute Myeloid Leukemia (AML) Patients by Treatment Outcome
text:
Project Summary

In this project, we analyzed clinical data from 429 patients diagnosed with Acute Myeloid Leukemia (AML) a type of blood cancer. The dataset was obtained from the Genomic Data Commons (GDC) a comprehensive platform maintained by the National Cancer Institute (NCI) that provides open access to cancer genomics datasets.


Number of Patients by Treatment Outcome and Gender

Before visualizing survival outcomes, we included a summary table that displays the total number of patients by treatment outcome and gender. This table helps contextualize the distribution of treatment responses across male and female patients, while also highlighting the prevalence of missing or unreported treatment outcomes‚Äîa common challenge in analyzing real-world clinical datasets.

Survival Analysis of Acute Myeloid Leukemia (AML) Patients by Treatment Outcome







 The interactive plot above visualizes clinical data from patients diagnosed with AML.

Each Dot: Represents an individual patient
Dot Color: Gender of the patient

X-axis: Survival time (years)
Y-axis: Treatment outcome (Complete Response, Unknown, or Not Reported)

The treatment outcomes include:

Complete Response ‚Äì meaning the patient responded well to treatment
Unknown ‚Äì outcome is unclear or ambiguous
Not Reported ‚Äì outcome data is missing from the medical record

The plot helps identify patterns in survival patients with a ‚ÄúComplete Response‚Äù often show longer survival durations, while those with ‚ÄúUnknown‚Äù or ‚ÄúNot Reported‚Äù outcomes tend to have more scattered or shorter survival times.

Reminder The presence of missing data highlights challenges in analyzing real-world clinical datasets, where not every case is fully documented.
